hints.content: Start by understanding the problem: you need to remove exactly k elements from the array. Think about how removing elements affects the number of unique integers left in the array.
Consider how you might count the frequency of each integer in the array. This will help you determine which integers can be removed to minimize the number of unique integers remaining.
Use a data structure that allows you to easily count occurrences of each integer. A hash map (or dictionary) is a good choice for this task.
Once you have the counts, sort the integers based on their frequency. This will allow you to prioritize which integers to remove first.
Think about how to handle ties in frequency. If two integers have the same frequency, you can choose to remove either; focus on removing the ones with the lowest frequency first.
After sorting, iterate through the sorted list of frequencies and start removing elements. Keep track of how many elements you've removed and how many unique integers remain.
Pay attention to the case when k is larger than the total number of unique integers. What should the output be in that case?
Consider edge cases, such as when the array has only one unique integer or when k is zero. How do these scenarios affect your approach?
As you remove elements, update your count of unique integers. Make sure to stop once you've removed exactly k elements.

Finally, think about the return value. You need to return the count of unique integers left after performing the removals. Ensure your final count reflects any adjustments made during the removal process.

questionNotes: You must remove exactly k elements from the array.
The output should be the least number of unique integers remaining after the removals.
